entry.content:
• Wanna know more about native notifications in the browser? Check out this post by Adam Fortuna.

  • Now this post on full-text search using only CSS is a neat trick, but probably not one you wanna use for real.

  • Looking for a responsive navigation for your next site design? Check out Responsive Nav.

  • breakOn is a nifty little Javascript snippet to add to your Chrome dev tools, that will cause a break upon a given event.

  • grunt newer is a Grunt task that will only run a task against files that have been modified since the last run.

  • HTML5 Boilerplate gets a new release. 4.3 includes a bunch of fixes, and updates several of its dependencies.

  • LoDash also gets a new release, and a major one at that. Version 2.0 get custom builds, and a few new methods, including _.curry.

  • Is WebRTC ready yet? Check out this site which shows a nice table of the latest browser support.

And finally...

  • JSFuck is a new language based on Javascript, that uses only six characters to write and execute code. Best name ever!

My goal is to try to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.

entry.content:
• HTML5 Rocks have written another one of their expertly written posts, this time on custom HTML elements.

  • UIBox is a library of curates HTML, Javascript and CSS components.

  • Perimeter.js is a JS library that will create a invisible perimeter around a target element, and then monitors mouse breaches.

  • CSSTricks have written about the HTML5 Progress element, and it's another good read.

  • FancySelect is a JS library that will turn your select boxes into a sexy beast!

  • The BatmanJS site just got a facelift.

  • Joel Turnbull asks the question: Does CoffeeScript has a future? Which after reading his post, is a fair question to ask. Simply because Javascript is evolving at a much faster rate than it has in the past. But I still digg Coffeescript!

entry.content:
• The increasingly popular Javascript framework; Ember, has hit a final 1.0.0 release over the weekend. Check out their updated site and docs.

  • SetJS is a library that provides Python inspired data sets to Javascript.

  • This is a great video of a talk Lea Verou gave all about the humble border-radius.

  • Probe is a neat little library that extends the Javascript native prototypes with Lo-Dash or Underscore methods.

  • CSS Creatures is a collection of fun animated smiley faces, all written in CSS.

  • AdminJS is a backend-agnostic admin framework. Meaning you can boot up an HTML page with this library included, and after defining your models, you have a fully fledged admin backend.

  • And just for fun, I give you... a Javascript Piano!

entry.content:
Happy Friday! ...again

  • Intention.js is a very interesting, but slightly strange Javascript library that offers a way to dynamically restructure your HTML in a responsive manner using HTML attributes. And that's why I don't like it. Ends up dirtying your HTML.

  • Flipload.js provides a nice way to flip your HTML elements to show a loading indicator. Works with pretty much any element, which is nice.

  • I've seen these Parallax style effects before, but this library demo's what it can do very nicely indeed!

  • Ariya Hidayat writes an interesting article all about searching with Array.some().

  • This article on CSS sprites vs. Data URI's analyses which is faster and more efficient, particularly on mobile devices.

entry.content:
Quarter of a century!

  • Love Handlebars? Love Swag! A huge and extremely useful collection of Handlebars helpers.

  • Need to generate a PDF or two? well you don't need the server anymore. jsPDF will let you generate PDF files in client-side Javascript.

  • Seems we have a new UI pattern - nanoscopic progress bars! NProgress.js is a Javascript library that allows you to create such a progress bar.

  • MobileHTML is a nifty site similar to CanIUse, with a focus on mobile browsers.

  • DeveloperDrive have written a great post on multiple backgrounds in CSS3, which includes a nice fun demo.

My goal is to try to publish every week day, so I would appreciate any help. If you find anything that you think would deserve a place in future issues, please let me know.
